summary: This is a reply memorandum filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team in support of a motion to suppress evidence obtained from a grand jury subpoena issued to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP. The motion argues the government violated Maxwell's Fourth Amendment, Fifth Amendment, and due process rights by obtaining 90,000 pages of confidential material without proper notice and through misleading the court. It seeks suppression of all evidence from the subpoena and dismissal of Counts Five and Six (perjury counts) of her indictment.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, filing a motion to suppress evidence obtained from her former civil litigation attorneys and to dismiss perjury counts against her.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, signatory on the reply memorandum.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed on the filing from HADDON, MORGAN & FOREMAN P.C.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from COHEN & GRESSER LLP, signatory on the certificate of service.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, listed on the filing from the Law Offices of Bobbi C. Stemheim.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Named partner of Boies Schiller Flexner LLP, referenced as having complained about the government not charging Maxwell with perjury.

persons.name: Judge Sweet
persons.context: Presiding judge in the civil defamation case (v. Maxwell) who issued a pre-deposition order and the original protective order. Deceased by the time of this filing.

persons.name: Chief Judge McMahon
persons.context: Judge who modified the protective order in the civil case to allow the government's subpoena to Boies Schiller. The motion alleges she was misled by the government.

persons.name: Judge Preska
persons.context: Judge presiding over the unsealing process in the civil case (v. Maxwell) after Judge Sweet's death. The motion notes she is unaware the protective order was modified.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as Maxwell's co-conspirator, with the civil case described as a 'proxy prosecution' of him and Maxwell.

connections.description: Referenced together as subjects of the civil defamation case which is described as a 'proxy prosecution' for alleged trafficking and abuse.
Boies Schiller was the law firm representing the plaintiff in a civil defamation case against Maxwell, during which her confidential depositions and materials were generated.
David Boies's firm sued Maxwell, and he is alleged to have collaborated with the government, potentially setting a 'perjury trap'.

The motion alleges the government and Boies Schiller collaborated, with the firm acting as an 'agent of the state' by meeting with prosecutors and potentially withholding discovery to facilitate a perjury case.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition was taken in the civil defamation case. She testified without invoking the Fifth Amendment, relying on the protective order.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's second deposition was taken in the civil defamation case. Testimony from this deposition forms the basis of perjury charges (Counts 5 & 6).

events.title: Meeting between Boies Schiller and Government
events.description: A meeting occurred between attorneys from Boies Schiller and federal prosecutors, where depositions were discussed and the government contemplated a perjury prosecution.

events.title: Filing of Reply Memorandum
events.description: Maxwell's defense team files this reply memorandum in support of the motion to suppress evidence from Boies Schiller and dismiss perjury counts.

events.title: Government Opens Investigation
events.description: The government claims it opened its investigation of Maxwell in 2018, but the defense argues it began earlier, in 2016.

keyFacts: The government obtained approximately 90,000 pages of confidential material from the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP via a grand jury subpoena, which Maxwell's defense seeks to suppress.

The defense argues the government violated Maxwell's rights by misleading Chief Judge McMahon to modify a protective order and issue the subpoena without giving Maxwell notice or an opportunity to be heard.
Counts Five and Six of the indictment are perjury charges based on Maxwell's April and July 2016 deposition testimony in a civil defamation case.
The defense alleges Boies Schiller acted as an 'agent of the state' by collaborating with prosecutors, potentially setting a 'perjury trap' for Maxwell during her depositions.
The motion claims the government's investigation into Maxwell began as early as 2016, contradicting its public claim that it started in 2018.
